awd_titl_txt: Redox-Responsive Hydrogen-Bonding Systems for Supramolecular Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Inspired by the iconic example of DNA, which is composed of two strands of natural polymers that are held together by weak forces and can be separated when desired, Professor Smith of San Diego State University explores novel approaches to controlling the reversible assembly and separation of synthetic polymer strands.  Such polymeric materials offer the potential for correction of defects and stimuli-responsive properties.  In addition to the potential for significant impact in responsive materials, supramolecular polymers and switches, this research program provides excellent education and training opportunities to a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students, many of whom are from groups under-represented in science.  This research project encourages students to decipher what is  happening at the molecular level - sharpening their chemical reasoning and problem solving abilities.  These abilities are valuable in their future careers. 

The overall goal of this project is to develop the chemistry of redox-active, linear hydrogen-bond dimers such that binding strength can be strongly, but reversibly, perturbed by electrochemical reduction/oxidation.  This research program is broken into three specific aims. Aim 1 is to establish the significance of two electrons and one proton (H+) verse one electron transfer for strongly perturbing hydrogen bonding by comparing the voltammetric behavior of these two types of systems.  Aim 2 is to develop new redox-active hydrogen bond dimers in which proton transfer across a hydrogen bond is purposely used to amplify the effect of electron transfer in such a way that binding strength is either greatly increased or decreased. Finally, in Aim 3, the research team explores the use of the redox-active arrays developed to create redox-responsive, supramolecular, polymeric systems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project explored new methods to selectively control the strength of interactions between molecules using electron transfer by itself and in combination with proton transfer.  The molecules involved can be thought of as synthetic relatives of the natural base pairs that link together the two strands of the DNA double helix using hydrogen bonds or H-bonds.  These weak, but highly selective interactions, are based on the electrostatic attraction between relatively positively charged hydrogen atoms and relatively negatively charged atoms such as oxygen or nitrogen. By using multiple H-bonds, the natural base pairs link together in a highly specific fashion, a feature necessary for the reliable transfer of genetic information.  In the synthetic versions investigated in this project, the linkages also are highly specific, but, unlike their natural cousins, the strength of the linkages are controllable, reversibly going from weaker to stronger or vice-versa by using electron transfer to alter the charge on the atoms involved in the H-bonds, and thereby affect the strength of the H-bonds.

Although much of the work in this project was quite fundamental in nature, being aimed at determining the sometimes subtle factors that affect the magnitude of the binding strengths, two systems with particular large differences in binding strength stood out.  The first forms a homo-dimer (meaning that it pairs with itself) through four H-bonds. Upon removal of an electron (oxidation) from an iron(II) center in the molecule to give iron(III), the dimer essentially completely breaks apart with a 6,000,000-fold decrease in binding strength. The likely explanation for this very strong effect is that oxidation of the iron decreases the negative charge on all the H-accepting atoms in the four H-bonds holding the dimer together. The process, however, is completely reversible, with full binding strength returned upon addition of an electron (reduction) to convert the iron(III) back to iron(II).

The other standout redox-responsive H-bonding system discovered in this project is one in which reduction (addition of electrons) greatly increases the binding strength between an electroactive component and its non-electroactive binding partner in a three H-bond hetero-dimer (each component is different).  The notable feature in this system is that the electron transfer induces proton transfer across the central H-bond in the dimer and in so doing switches the secondary H-bonds (these are the weaker H-bonds between atoms located diagonally from each other) from all unfavorable to all favorable.  This amplifies the effect of the initial electron transfer, which on its own would only increase the strength of the central H-bond.  The result is a 200,000-fold increase in binding strength upon reduction, with a factor of 1000 coming from the proton transfer based on comparison to related systems.  This represents an entirely new and powerful strategy for the design of highly redox-responsive H-bond dimers, one which was originally hypothesized in the Project proposal and has now been demonstrated to be viable through this example.

One advantage of using electron transfer as the means to control binding strength is that it provides a straightforward interface with current electronic devices for possible applications. In the short term the highly selective ON/OFF binding observed in the systems described above may find use in a variety of smart materials and sensing systems, and, in the longer term, molecular devices and machines.  However, irrespective of whether such applications come to fruition, the research has already provided significant new fundamental knowledge regarding the interactions between electron transfer, H-bonding and proton transfer. In addition, it has provided excellent training and education to the many students who have participated in and contributed towards the outcomes of this project over the course of the grant. This includes 6 graduate students, 19 undergraduate students and 1 high school student. Of these, 17 are women and 12 come from racial/ethnic groups underrepresented in the sciences.  So far, 5 papers based on project results have been published in peer-reviewed journals and 4 M.S. Theses and 15 Senior Project Reports written.  In addition, the P.I. gave 18 presentations and the students 26 presentations at major scientific conferences on the results of this project.


Last Modified: 01/03/2022
Modified by: Diane K Smith
